title: How could parents encourage their kids to read books nowadays? - Quora

response.answer_text: Let them read anything that appeals to them. I was a library mom at my child's school and read things to the kids like Captain Underpants, Dumb Bunnies and of course, Dr. Suess! I battled the school librarian regularly over my book choices that she considered to be “tasteless” or in the case of Dr. Suess, “liberal indoctrination.” She wanted me to read only things like Johnny Tremaine and other old, dry children's lit from her childhood. It used to irritate her to see the kids line up to check out the books I read to them! I didn't care if a book contained fart jokes or precocious children… whatever sparked a desire to read was worth reading.

I started reading to my kids at a very young age. When they were around a year old and beginning to use words I sat them on my lap and read to them. So I didn't read the actual story but I pointed to the pictures and got them to say what they saw in the picture. Once they were old enough to speak in actual sentences I read them books. Doctor Seuss "Hop on Pop" was an early favorite. They knew it by heart and were able to "read" it to me. This persuaded them that they could read. So I let them read it to me. Bedtime story is a very important ritual for little kids and once they begin to read, they can read you some of the bedtime story. When they were older, I made sure that they had a lot of books available for them to read, and after going to bed, they were allowed to read in bed for half an hour before going to sleep. We also limited television and computer time so they were encouraged to read instead.Today they are voracious bookworms...

Read to them books that are genuinely exciting and immersive, not ones that are there just to teach a sweet lesson. Some books do both, of course, but so often parents give their little kids books along the lines of “little bear learns to share” and wonder why kids think books are boring. If 5 year olds are exposed to books featuring Greek mythology, fart jokes, and magic, they become accustomed to the idea that books are a pleasure. From then on, it’s just a question of continuing to give them books that provide them with joys they cannot obtain elsewhere.

create a culture of reading in the home. keep books accessible in the home. Does the parent read, in front of the kids? If kids see parents reading, they will inherently understand the reading is not simply a drudgery that one must learn in school, but a form of communication that will be useful ALL throughout their lives. Use technology only where it is supplemental. When my homeschooled kids ask a question, I cringe when my husband is like “OKAY GOOGLE”, I’m like “NOOO… this is a great opportunity to go to the library and get a ton of books and do some research”. Reinforce the idea that information in print is the way to go. I take them to the library when they are interested in something and get like 10 books on the subject for them to absorb.

I have raised three sons and they all have a love of books. I read them stories in the afternoon for their quiet time and we went to the library to the children’s section to allow them to choose their own books. This teaches them responsibility (they need to keep track of the books, take care of the books and to return the books on time) It teaches them that the world is a larger place than just their local area, and it teaches them adventure. We were fortunate to live in a beautiful area of California and they also loved exploring (Yosemite Valley and surrounding areas. We lived in an old mining town called Sonora) So, read to them, make books available to them, read them the books they choose, and keep them active outside. I was lucky enough to be a stay at home mother while they were small and this helped also. Children need supervision and love.

In addition to reading to them, letting them pick books, reading alongside them, and later only allowing the movie (mostly Harry Potter) after the book was read; we didn’t do electronics (until they were the last in their class with out a phone at 12, bleah) or tv, just movies once a week and educational games on my computer on weekends, and also, they were given reading lights around age 9 and allowed to stay up later if they wanted to read.

The best way is for parents to read books themselves, though reading aloud together (e.g., through a novel by Dickens) is also a good exercise. Children emulate their parents. If you are reading books a lot, so will your children, generally speaking. If you don’t read books, then “do as a say, not as I do” has never been very convincing.

I'm a child and I have always enjoyed reading. I remember when I got a Kindle for my 6th birthday, I made it so that Everytime you read for 20 minutes it tells you parent. When I was being stubborn and wouldn't read a book that my mom knew I would love, she said to read to a certain page and if I didnt like, don't finish the book. Tl;Dr Challenge your child and reward them when they should be rewarded.

The trick I used when my boys were growing up was to start a book for them at bedtime, just the first chapter of an engaging book. Set it down on their nightstand and the next thing you know they are reading it because you caught their interest and they want to see what happens next. My sons are prolific readers to this day, 20 years later.
Start them off by reading books to them. If you go on road trips, play books on tape, err, cd, err, mp3 for them. Then introduce them to age appropriate books they can read on their own.
Read to them Let them see YOU reading Turn off the TV and Computer and have a time where everyone reads Set up rewards for reading
Read to them when they’re small. Read yourself. discuss what you’re reading and ask them to tell you about what they’re reading.
